author: SDzbenski

description.text:
please do not print any file at the moment, they are FAR from finished and simply uploaded to allow me to post this!

Hi all,

I was recently given a new, But assembled K8200. It is missing a few parts (hot end and wiring mainly) so ive decided to try and turn it into something a little special!

I noticed the core-XY design by Agence_akira but the project looks to be incomplete/dead so have decided to redesign it.

I plan to design it using as many original parts as I can.
It will require no cutting of any original parts.

extra parts that cant be printed (any there will be many of them needed!) will be standard parts that can be cheaply gotten from Aliexpress.

The printer will have duel bearing supported Z-screws with a single bottom mounted stepper with a closed loop belt driving the second z screw

I also plan to build it with the thought of it all being enclosed which will also add strength.

So far ive designed the Z mount parts which are currently printing,

Photos and files will be added as I go along.

comments and thoughts are highly appretiated!

Printer:

K8200
All printable parts drew on Sketchup.

print_settings.Notes:: Ensure good bed adhesion and correct extruder calibration.

description.text:
This has been replaced by V3 https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2641147

Parametric SMT Tape Feeders for OpenPnp or other Pick and Place machines. You can customize the holders for any sized tape limited only by your print bed size. Before wasting your time printing a huge array I suggest a small 20mm 8x1 two tray model to ensure your extruder is properly calibrated. Also be sure your choice of filament has good bed adhesion.

This replaces the old version https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2396616 and improves performance. By default the base cut outs are disabled since this made the tape unstable and components sometimes jumped out. In addition you can now create a ledge under the holes by specifying the tape thickness (different to height) this gives much better performance on plastic tapes.

Finally the end stop has been removed so that the tape can be extended past the pickup position to allow feed from reels without having to remove the tape to get rid of the used section.

Printer:

TS3D Prusa inspired

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Ensure good bed adhesion and correct extruder calibration.

Assembly

You will probably want glue the two halves together, use a bit of superglue in the slots of the press fit or if you print in ABS perhaps acetone. I fasten the final unit to the machine bed using fine craft tape.

OpenScad

I used OpenScad thus the part is fully parametric, the fillets take a while to render you could disable them but print quality is often better with rounded corners.

title: TronXY P802 PSUCover switch, no socket.

description.text:
This is a remix of:
Power Supply Cap for 250-12-20 by lacrimosa2k2
Published on March 31, 2016
www.thingiverse.com/thing:1455084

Disclaimer: Only someone who is trained to safely work with electrical equipment should use this. There is no warranty or claim of fitness for purpose or any responsibility taken by me. Make sure everything is unplugged before installing. Mains voltages can be lethal so make sure you use a fused wire. Be safe everyone. The aim of this object is safety.

It is for the S-240-12 power supply. It is secured by three bolts to the original frame holes, but I only use two in the 12V compartment. Feed wires through before mounting permanently with M3 bolts and nuts.

This is customisable. There is a switch hole for an illuminated 15A switch, which is much more than this application needs as the mains is stepped down by a factor of 20 to get 12V for 240V mains. The wire is permanent and I used two strain reliefs from a "choc box" terminal box, but I guess you could print these if you wanted. Those are held on with self-tapping screws.

There is a separator for the mains voltage part and the 12V part of the PSU terminals.

There are air holes.

There are holes for the z axis motor connector to pass through but these are a little tight and I had to put the connector in horizontally. You can change this if you want in the scad file using a CAD program of your choice.

The stock PSU is not made perfectly square in my case so there is a tiny gap when mounted.

Printer:

TronXY P802MA

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Support pattern 4mm in Slic3r helps the supports come away easily.
Adjust the switch hole to match your switch size.
200 degree extruder, 60 degree bed, 0.4mm first layer height, 3mm brim, 3 loop skirt, PLA.

So I printed out some of these hinges, at ~95% scale, and they look awesome, but they don't actually fit together :(
I think the design doesn't take into account plastic shrinkage etc at all. Anybody have any thoughts for how to make these such that they can actually fit together?
comments.author: jlpatte2

comments.text: Hi man, print out the innerpart (male part) 1% smaller...this is for a pretty precise printer. Very low tolerance. You could also set your horizontal size to compensate for, say -.5mm. Try some stuff out and print it upside down starting at the part that slides in the other part so you can cancel the print and see if it fits. When it fits print the whole thing!

description.text:
This adjustable bushing helps with differences in printing tolerances by allowing one half to flex. The screw holes help hold the flexible half in position with the added benefit to adjust for wear. The screw holes are sized for an M3 screw to self thread in.

7/16/2017 Uploaded a version that has 3 layers for the outer shell.At the cost of its OD, witch is at 15.80mm. This and prevents things like zip ties and retaining clips from deforming it as much.

7/4/2017 Revision 3 has the bushing half shell attached to the outer shell just on the one side. This helps retain the bearing and yet it still able to move and be adjusted. This version also does not need to be printed on a raft anymore. The next/final revision will happen at a later date as i plan on running this bearing in my printer to see how it holds up. I also plan on cleaning up the model later as the boolean operations i did messed with some of the faces.

7/3/2017 i added a second revision i added more around the screw holes and removed the slopes. It seems to print fine with out it, and it leaves room for zip ties. I'm also working on a third revision that helps retain the half shell so its less likely to slide out.

author: Gepetto

description.text:
I'm setting up my very first vivarium to house poison dart frogs. It seems these frogs will want a stream or waterfall in their home. I don't really want a waterfall in my first viv so I'm going to make a stream.

I've thrown together some really gross openscad source and am in the process of printing these parts in ABS with the intention of welding them together once finished.

I'm hoping to get about a 2 degree fall to the stream. I plan to line it with glass pebbles or aquarium gravel.

The tray in the pool should allow 3mm of water or so to build up so the frogs can take a dip without drowning.

author: Tentho

title: Blasthook Gunship 28mm
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hi all !

I have been looking for a Stormtalon proxy for a long time and decided to make my own :

Here is the final version of my Stormtalon proxy : I called it BlastHook

It was much inspired by GW's stormtalon, but was modelled all freehand, only based on pictures. It still has some differences. Nearly everything was designed with Meshmixer. I borrowed some parts here and there (engine intake, missile launchers, space marine...)

It should be correctly scaled for 28mm, as I placed a 28mm space marine inside.

Features :

  • Engines can rotate vertically
  • Front autocannon can rotate horizontally
  • Side weapons could be changed, if necessary
  • I modelled a cockpit internal detail, with a 2nd ed Space marine inside (thx Garin).
  • And the tail has a retractable landing pad inside
  • A 6mm hole under the main hull, for a base

All in all, it is pretty easy to print, some parts need supports (only from print bed). Choose orientations wisely.
Assembly is really straightforward; on the body assembly i included some square locating pins that will help position parts together.
The canopy is tricky to print, I made mine by printing the part unfold; fold the different faces, and glue on small spots. It needs some transparent plastic sheet to have a glass effect.

Sorry for the heavy files, I am not very efficient with meshmixer, and meshes tend to be very dense.

I had a great time working on this Gunship, the result is worth the time spent on it.

PLEASE SHARE YOUR PRINTS !! :D

Copyright infringement is not intended. All parts and modifications are created freehand in 3d modeling software, no copyrighted product had been scanned or copied in any way.

title: RotorX Atom Camera mount for V3 canopy
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I (With AlderBoy's permission) have altered the original design to work with the new V3 canopy.

The V2 canopy is slightly smaller, and so the regular mount when placed inside of it has a gap from the top (Or bottom) of the mount base to the canopy, and frame. This has been shown to cause some jello.

I increased the thickness of the base so that it not flush fits the canopy, and gets sandwiched between the canopy, and the frame better, for a more solid fit.

These will now be included in all Atom kits moving forward from RotorX. I am putting the file up here for all to use.

Do not use this to sell or make money on, unless you have already contacted Myself, or Alderboy, or another member of the RotorX team.

I can include a 10deg mount if wanted.

This is designed for True Nunjaflex filament to minimize jello, and to allow the camera to be popped in, and out (No cutting is required)

You can also print it in TPU, but you will need to cut the mount down the middle of the base to get camera in, and out.

Print at 40-55% infill depending on the material, and infill pattern.

A quick parametric gearbox generator, upgraded to support helical spur gears. Use a separate program to combine components if you want to print them all at once. This is NOT a print in place!

I used ReplicatorG to shift all the models to the print bed and flip the top cover plate, then blender to combine all the models into one file for the print.

As with previous post, this is tested. The included stl files are for the NEMA17 gearbox with which tests were carried out. It was found that it prints with a 0.4 mm nozzle, but it helps to run the gearbox for a period of time with some autosol chrome polish to aid working-in. Once it's sounding quieter, clean and grease before reassembly.

Hardware required for generated models: 3x 3mm dia.~ 18 mm shafts for the planet gears. M3/ ~20 mm screws to affix to NEMA17 motor. Also, it helps to add 6 washers - one above and one below each planet gear to separate them from the carrier.

NOTE: Files to print are HelicalGears.stl for the gearing, and NoGears.stl for the other bits of structure (planet carrier, top and bottom plate).

The main reason behind this was to find out if helical gears are quieter or not. Turns out they're not really, at least with the twist I have on them. Not sure it's worth it for the extra difficulty involved in assembly! Might be as well sticking with https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2410859 although this scad file generates the same models if "DblHelixTwist" is set to 0.

Small update: Have compared the two gearboxes more carefully - at ~150 RPM input, the helical model is definitely quieter than the straight spur-gear version. Plan to test a DblHelixTwist = 80 version next.

Butterfly # 41

Search "wslab" for more designs.

description.text:
This is part of a set of customizable Lego compatible robotics components. This post is for Lego compatible mounts for an Arduino nano with an expansion board (an UNO would also fit as it is the same profile).

Files Included:
A brick that covers the nano so you can make use of the space on top.
A case for a 9V battery and mount for a breadboard that can snap to the top of the cover.
A version of the nano-cover with a space for holding a dual motor driver.
A 2x2 brick for holding a buzzer. (useful for trouble shooting robots)
*A customizer for standard Lego bricks

All parts shown printed in ABS, but I've also successfully printed with semi flexible TPU. Printing Legos is tricky, see the print settings section for tips.

ABS filament: http://amzn.to/2tzUZoR
TPU filament: http://amzn.to/2uzk3Ja

Arduino Nano Expansion Board: http://amzn.to/2tgceZK
Arduino Nano + cord: http://amzn.to/2tFSzp3
Battery Clip & dc plug: http://amzn.to/2tBmpdo
Rechargeable 9V Battery: http://amzn.to/2tzN9v9
Solderless Breadboard: http://amzn.to/2tzJNbB
Motor Driver: http://amzn.to/2tFNzkf
Electronic Buzzer: http://amzn.to/2uzgCCu
Solderless Jumper Wires: http://amzn.to/2tA9MzE

Also be sure to check out my collection of the best customizable Lego parts on Thingiverse: https://www.thingiverse.com/MechEngineerMike/collections/customizable-legos

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 Max

Infill:

Any

Notes:

3D Printing Legos is tricky but it can be done if your printer is tuned well. This model is designed to match Lego bricks perfectly, nothing is scaled.

If you print it and the stud or base is too tight/loose then your printer needs adjusting, not the model. (Else you end up with weird settings that only work for one specific type of Lego... trust me I've printed a lot of Legos!)

I recommend printing the calibration brick and getting your calipers out, then see attached image for dimensions. (Or just grab a regular 2x4 brick to measure)

These are my recommendations for tuning the printer:

  • Change your extrusion multiplier, but never scale the model.
    Turn on 'detect thin walls'.
    Turn on 'print external perimeters first' to ensure that path-overlap doesnt cause your critical outer surfaces to shift.
    *Printing with nozzle diameter .4mm or less, Layer height .2mm or less.

*If all else fails and you want to rescue an imperfect brick, blast it with a heatgun for a few seconds then press it onto a real Lego and let cool. Careful, this can easily ruin bricks too.

*Ive printed Legos successfully in ABS, PETG, and TPU. The hard materials are unforgiving, but feel like real Legos if done right. The TPU bricks fall off easier but are also easier to print successfully.

comments.text: I am a big fan of all of your lego-compatible robotics blocks.  I've recently learned that my old Mindstorms kit is no longer supported by current-generation operating systems.  I tried a 32-bit virtual machine and had no luck communicating with the hardware.  I have a 7-year-old who is a master of Lego blocks but neither he nor I do well building in the purely Tecnhix blocks of the current generation Mindsorms.  So my old-school RCX brick won't work, and the new-generation is a pain.  I did what any hacker-dad should and made it a fun project for both of us.

title: Automatic Maoam candy dispenser with servo - Arduino controlled

description.text:
This is a automatic candy dispenser as possible for MAOAM.

1) Print the dispenser and the gear
2) Put the gear on a SG90 servo and fix it with the screws inside of the SG90 package.
3) Fix the servo with two screws on the dispenser (also inside of the SG90 package)
4) Connect the servo to anny Arduino microcontroller (or a clone like Funduino) and write a sketch to controll the servo. The servo can be activated by a pressed button or by a hand that approachs a distance sensor for example.

Now if the servo gets activated, the dispenser throws out a candy.

Upgrade:
You can print a plate for the bottom and the top to create a bigger dispenser with a pipe between the plates, that can be combines with LED lights an so on (pictures!)

Dies ist ein automatischer Süßigkeiten-Dispenser wie möglich für MAOAM.
1) Drucken Sie den Spender, das Zahnrad und die Zahnstange aus
2) Befestigen Sie das Zahnrad mit einer Schraube am SG90 Servo (Im SG90-Paket enthalten)
3) Befestigen Sie das Servo mit zwei Schrauben am Spender (Auch im SG90-Paket enthalten)

4) Verbinden Sie den Servo mit dem Funduino-Mikrocontroller und schreiben Sie einen Sketch, um das Servo zu steuern. Das Servo kann beispielsweise durch einen gedrückten Knopf oder durch eine Hand aktiviert werden, die sich einem Distanzsensor nähert.

Wenn das Servo aktiviert wird, wirft der Spender eine Süßigkeit aus.

Aktualisierung:
Sie können eine Platte für die Unterseite und die Oberseite eines Rohrstückes drucken, um einen größeren Spender zu schaffen, der mit LED-Lichtern kombiniert werden kann.

SG90 servos und Mikrocontroller haben wir hier gefunden:
www.funduinoshop.com

Das Filament ist von:
www.filamentplatz.de

Combine 3d-printing with simple electronics and microcontrolling This project combines 3d-printing with simple electronics and microcontrolling. Its a good idea to teach the pupils in a easy way to construct a functional model of a dispenser. Very usefull in lessons of beginning with Arduino microcontrolling.

Ho to produce a automatic candy dispenser for MAOAM. 1) Print the dispenser and the gear
2) Put the gear on a SG90 servo and fix it with the screws inside of the SG90 package.
3) Fix the servo with two screws on the dispenser (also inside of the SG90 package)
4) Connect the servo to anny Arduino microcontroller (or a clone like Funduino) and write a sketch to controll the servo. The servo can be activated by a pressed button or by a hand that approachs a distance sensor for example. Now if the servo gets activated, the dispenser throws out a candy. Upgrade:
You can print a plate for the bottom and the top to create a bigger dispenser with a pipe between the plates, that can be combines with LED lights an so on (pictures!)

Requirements Filament:

title: Paint Brush Cleaner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
It might be hard to capture exactly what it does in pictures, but essentially it has a slot you slide your brush into that pinches and wrings the brush. Fill with some water or paint thinner, and it should help you get most of the paint off without a mess. Should also use paint thinner more efficiently.

Make sure to print in the proper materials as to not melt the plastic, and print thick enough so that it doesn't leak. I printed at 1.2mm walls @ 0.2mm layer height @ 20% infill and it's 100% waterproof.

The brush slot starts out at 1mm wide and shrinks down to 0.4mm. So keep in mind that if you want to use it for large thicker brushes, scale it accordingly. This size is more suited to smaller detailing brushes, but can work with larger brushes too. Can easily hold multiple brushes, which can be cleaned one by one without interfering with each other. It's really a more convenient design than it looks at first glance.

print_settings.Notes:: *Ive printed Legos successfully in ABS, PETG, and TPU. The hard materials are unforgiving, but feel like real Legos if done right. The TPU bricks fall off easier but are also easier to print successfully.

description.text:
This is part of a set of customizable Lego compatible robotics components. This post is for Lego compatible profile shifted bricks.

Files Included:
A brick that translates the studs by 4mm or 1/2 of standard Lego spacing.
A brick that rotates the studs by 45 deg.
*A brick intended for holding a marker.

Green & red parts shown printed in ABS, but the black part is semi flexible TPU. Printing Legos is tricky, see the print settings section for tips.

ABS filament: http://amzn.to/2tzUZoR
TPU filament: http://amzn.to/2uzk3Ja

Also be sure to check out my collection of the best customizable Lego parts on Thingiverse: https://www.thingiverse.com/MechEngineerMike/collections/customizable-legos

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 Max

Infill:

any

Notes:

3D Printing Legos is tricky but it can be done if your printer is tuned well. This model is designed to match Lego bricks perfectly, nothing is scaled.

If you print it and the stud or base is too tight/loose then your printer needs adjusting, not the model. (Else you end up with weird settings that only work for one specific type of Lego... trust me I've printed a lot of Legos!)

I recommend printing the calibration brick and getting your calipers out, then see attached image for dimensions. (Or just grab a regular 2x4 brick to measure)

These are my recommendations for tuning the printer:

  • Change your extrusion multiplier, but never scale the model.
    Turn on 'detect thin walls'.
    Turn on 'print external perimeters first' to ensure that path-overlap doesnt cause your critical outer surfaces to shift.
    *Print with nozzle diameter .4mm or less, Layer height .2mm or less.

*If all else fails and you want to rescue an imperfect brick, blast it with a heatgun for a few seconds then press it onto a real Lego and let cool. Careful, this can easily ruin bricks too.

*Ive printed Legos successfully in ABS, PETG, and TPU. The hard materials are unforgiving, but feel like real Legos if done right. The TPU bricks fall off easier but are also easier to print successfully.

description.text:
Kossel part cooling fan
Works with Kossel Mini and Kossel XL

I updated this to include both a single and double duct.
Both clear the standard Kossel Probe.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

RepRap Kossel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.24

Infill:

10%

I wanted a compact part cooling fan

There are several part cooling fans. I didn't want to lose any space on my Mni Kossel. I didn't want to add to the complexity of the effector. I wanted something simple. It had
to work with the stock e3d v6. I have a Kossel XL as well. I have plenty of room on the effector of the Kossel XL. However, i want one design to work on both.

This is simple. Print all parts. No Supports. Print one bracket. A 50mmx15mm fan
fits in the adapter. The bracket supports the fan in the adapter. I use two 3mm screws to hold the fan. I only need one bracket to support the fan on the adapter. The fan adapter
slides into the blower nozzle.

The blower nozzle will use one of the screws that hold the e3d V6 to the effector.

7/3/2016
I uploaded a Fan Adapter with a hole present for the mounting screw. I increased
the nozzle diameter for better air flow.

This is another puzzle that I had in wood form, and wanted in plastic form.  
There are nine pieces which have to be assembled to form a 3d asterisk. There are only three different types of piece, so conceptually, it's not that hard. The last piece has to be pushed in kinda hard.  
I feel like I could have designed in a little better. When it's assembled, there's a little to much slack, but it still doesn't fall apart easily. Maybe in the future, I'll do a few more iterations and improve on it.  
Anyway, have fun.

description.text:
Three styles of elegance to spruce up your home.

If printed with a single-color printer, these can be easily painted with a foam brush. Lightly dab the entire front edge of the brush in paint, then lightly stroke it on the twisting lines on the outside of the vase, painting multiple lines at once.

I uploaded files for dual-color printers, but I don't have a dual-color printer, so I can't verify if I've prepared the files correctly. Somebody with the proper equipment--please let me know if it works!

If your vase has leaks, give it an acetone vapor bath (if you used ABS) to smooth out the surface and close the cracks, or paint the entire surface with a clear sealant.

"Vase mode" print setting not recommended.

Also see my candlestick holder which has a matching style: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2420926

Use your choice on other materials. Intended to carry the battery on the bottom, included battery strap slots to make a clean mount. 200 Stand off for mounting of the flight controller that allows you to manipulate your camera strap into place.

The Solar Panel bracket uses 10-24 threaded rod and 10-24 screws.

Most of the wire management objects I saw only allowed motion up and down. If you needed to make a turn, the part had to be stressed to make the turn. This incorporates a hollow axel between two sides of the traditional wire management piece. This allows it to turn not only up and down, but right, left, or any angle in between.

Resize in Cura to whatever size you need.

When I originally crafted my N7 armor to cosplay Commander Shepard, I used 2mm craft foam for the hand armor. I quickly found out that movement in the hands and holding prop guns causes the foam edges to wrinkle and chip paint, so I transferred the design to 3D and printed them in hard plastic. No more wrinkles! This simplistic design might be useful in other sci-fi and fantasy costumes as well.

My hands fit small gloves so I suggest taking measurements of your hands and scaling as desired prior to printing.

Commander Shepard, N7, Mass Effect, etc. are property of EA and BioWare.

October 9, 2017 edit: added an N7 emblem plate that goes on the breastplate because I'm a big baby that is triggered by people freehanding the font lol

I recommend using a dense or solid infill for these pieces. Black filament is a very good choice, as it prints easily and if the paint chips off will still look good. (Battle damaged!)

These pieces print flat so every layer is the same width and nothing requires supports. Heat them up with a heat gun on the low setting, then gently bend until you reach the desired curvature over your glove. I strongly suggest using pliers or tongs to hold the finger pieces over the heat gun to avoid burning yourself. The leg clips are optional depending on the model of armor you are making and do not require bending. All these pieces will adhere well to foam or fabric with contact cement.

description.text:
This is a remix of Acalabro13 awesome extruder modification. I basically lengthened it to clear the side of the Mini so that you can mount the extruder with the output facing up. Like this, the extruder for me no longer skips nor does it under extrude. I was having really bad under-extrusion on the left side of the bed because of how the PTFE tube would bend from the top to the carriage.

Note: You will need more PTFE tubing than what the Mini comes with

title: Belt clip clamp removeable for GT2-6 toothed belt zip tie alternative

description.text:
This is a remix of PRUSA I3 - Universal Belt Tie - Clip de courroie universel by jlcdi
Published on July 6, 2015
www.thingiverse.com/thing:913815

I printed an X axis tensioner but it reduced my axis travel as did the clip above. So instead I used a removable belt clip 4mm wide and experimented with tension. This worked without losing build volume. But it will need a periodic check. Note it can pop off at speeds of over 60mm/s so I made a stronger version 2 for higher speeds.

I adjusted the tension by moving it along one tooth at a time. It's hard to get really high tension this way but it's working for my purposes.

I included the scad file.

print_settings.Notes:: I specifically designed the holes in this to print without the need for supports, so you shouldn't need them, although some printer brands may struggle with the one small "bridge" that has to be formed. Also, due to the large base, you shouldn't need a raft.

description.text:
First, if you have any questions about this activity, feel free to leave a comment. If you want to rant about how climate change is a hoax, please stay quiet, this is not the place for debate.

This past summer, I've been aiding in teaching classes to middle schoolers, and I noticed that they tend to appreciate demos over lectures or videos. Although the target age for this demo is probably more like 4th grade, I assume 4th graders appreciate the same style of learning.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Normal/Medium

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I specifically designed the holes in this to print without the need for supports, so you shouldn't need them, although some printer brands may struggle with the one small "bridge" that has to be formed. Also, due to the large base, you shouldn't need a raft.

Polishing

Polishing the "glacial reserve" on the "east" side of "The United States" with something like acetone will help the water flow better, although no post-processing is necessary.

Onshape and Time

When began making this, I was on a family vacation, and this took me approximately 5 hours, making it my longest project for Thingiverse except for my Space Launch Complex 40 design. I just spent the evenings after dinner sitting on a chromebook measuring out fillets and shells and splines etc.
NGSS

Why I've found demos are important In aiding in a class to teach students to understand the lives of visually impaired people, I've noticed students are far more engaged when doing tactile activities with blindfolds etc. than the students were during presentations and lectures. I've also noticed that Climate Change isn't really a part of any curriculum, mainly because a lot of science curriculum haven't been updated in the past decade. If kids today are like I was at age 10, many of them would go home and talk to their parents about what they learned, which might help reduce the incredible misinformation around a settled science.

The Demo Groups of 4-6 kids will each be given the attached model, a cup of slightly soapy water, a paper towel, and an ice cube. Each group will be instructed to fill the model, which somewhat resembles the USA, to the "water fill line" mark with the soapy water. Each group will make sure that the raised "land" area is dry with a paper towel. Each group will place the ice cube on the "East" side of the demo, where the glacial reserves are. This "glacial reserves" are also to be considered land
.
A different activity can be taken in for about a half hour until the ice cubes melt. The groups will be asked to look at the models and see if the "lowlands" are still dry (They shouldn't be), and as a group discuss why the "sea" level rose (The ice on land melted, and the water from the ice flowed into the sea)

Materials PER GROUP Each group needs:
-1 Printed Model
-1 Cup of soapy water
-1 Ice Cube
-Paper Towels
1 hour

Setup Enough of the materials should be prepared for each group to use. It would also be ideal if the Teacher planned a quick discussion on how what the students are seeing in the demos is really happening as glaciers in Europe, Alaska, Russia, and Antarctica melt.
Participation Personally, I hate participation grades, but if students are engaged in the activity, they should earn full credit.
99/100 scientists. If anyone raises questions about the truth of climate change, it is unlikely their opinion will change. But 99/100 scientists are predicting something bad will happen.

title: Jokab-ABB Inca 22  E-Stop Switch Installation Tool

description.text:
This provides a tool that is not offered by the manufacturer, but is needed to get a solid mounting for the Jokab/ABB Inca 22 e-stop switch. Be sure to buy this switch with Jokab/ABB's adhesive e-stop legend disc. The tool will help you get it tight, but the switch can still rotate without the use of their adhesive legend disc. The index tab on this switch is fragile and too short to engage a legend disc and the panel.

The STL file includes support structure that helps build this vertically. You should print with support turned on in your slicing software and set for 30 degrees overhang or higher to handle the three horizontal rods and the curved area above the hex nut. The hole & cavity through the hex nut into the interior of the tool was created to force shell walls and make for a stronger transition from the hex nut to the hollow barrel.

It should be printed with the hex nut detail on the build plate and the open barrel facing up - to ensure the jam nut that jokab provides with the switch fits the tool correctly. The fit is very snug and holds the nut securely. Some users like the support structure and keep it for hand tightening, while others cut it off after printing and prefer using a socket wrench.

I hope this helps many Jokab-ABB inca users.

description.text:
I designed it using OpenJSCAD. JSCAD file is also shared. Following parameters can be adjusted in JSCAD for your need (if you are increasing top height to accommodate CPU FAN, then base height (BH) needs to be adjusted).

In base jscad, adjust these parameters

var BH=15; //base height. 15 for no SSD, 25 for with SATA SSD. 20 for only SATA SSD
var TH=27; //Top height. 25 might be better

In top, adjust these parameters for various fanMount holes.
var fanMount=union(mm40FanMount,mm50FanMount);
fanMount=mm40FanMount; //if you want both 40 and 50mm FAN mount uncomment

I was not having much success on usage of reset button assembly due my printer issue. It was getting broken. So settled for just one more cut/key hole for reset button.

In addition, ariflow duct on both sides of base acts as SATA connector cover. You need to use special right angled SATA connector. Cable will go over the top of the board and re-enter from other side to the base, where you can keep your SATA SSD

author: hewitt78

description.text:
8-27-2017 - I needed a mount for a standard endstop, so I modified the bracket. These will be very tight when screwed together with M3 bolts. The standard one doesn't yield more Y space.

7-3-2017 - I modified the back of the bracket to give more space, though I still recommend moving the cable holder to the rear bolt.

Also measured again on the machines using this. The bracket gets moved 6mm back. I believe it's only adding 5mm of space on the x axis based on the measurements. The switch triggers just before "closed" so that's likely the reason.

While repairing a parts mini, I noticed a couple of things about the Y limit switch. First, it was so close to the Y belt that the wiring for the switch was contacting the belt (this is not the case on my V2). Secondly, it was stopping the deck ~8mm forward of the Y carriage blocks, and there's an area of the build plate (where the leveling screws are) that's unusable as a result.

This switch moves the bracket left and back, yielding a very small addition to the Y axis. If you are already changing the belt, pulleys, or rerouting the wiring, this isn't a bad mod but it's probably not worth disassembly unless you REALLY need a minor Y increase.

To install this, unplug the printer.
Detension the Y belt (remove the spring clip, if you're still using it).
I like to clip the zip tie at the back of the bed (there's more slack there), and that releases the belt.
Remove the four screws holding the deck to the rods. Wrap the ends of the rod in masking tape so they don't slide out!
Now, disconnect the Y limit switch wiring (unplug it), and remove the limit switch bracket. Transfer the switch to the new bracket (remember, it's on the opposite side) and attach the bracket:

WARNING! The screws must be tightened ALL THE WAY DOWN, or the deck will hit them. On my V1 this worked as is. On my V2, I had to remove a washer.
There may be a plastic wire loop on your stepper closest to the switch - this should rotate easily so it doesn't contact, but if necessary, you can move it to the rear of the stepper motor.
Reconnect the switch, reattach the belt, re-wind and tension the belt, and you're up and running with an extremely minor increase in build space along the Y axis.

Turn it on, hit home, marvel at how the nozzle is now right on the edge of the build plate. There's actually more room to move the switch back, but without shifting the build plate, it's not usable, and it would only be a couple MM more. Only swapping in shorter slide bearings would make that rear space usable.

title: Advantages and Disadvantages of LiCoO2 Batteries and LiFePO4 Batteries

description.text:
Want to become familiar with the two different types of lithium-ion batteries: Lithium Cobalt Oxide (LiCoO2) and Lithium Iron Phosphate(LiFePO4) Lithium Cobalt Oxide, one of the most common Li-ions, has the chemical symbols LiCoO2 and the abbreviation LCO. And Lithium Iron Phosphate has the chemical symbols LiFePO4 and the abbreviation LFP.
Let us see their comparison.

  1. Comparison of Volume Energy Density
  2. Comparison of Quality Energy Density
  3. Comparison of Nominal Voltage
  4. Comparison of Normal Temperature Pulse Performance
  5. Comparison of Normal Temperature Pulse Cycle Performance（Blocking Temperature 55℃）
  6. Comparison of Pulse Discharge Performance（Temperature - 20℃）
  7. Comparison of Cycle Life（Temperature 20℃）
  8. Comparison of Full Electric High Temperature Storage Performance
  9. Comparison of Safety Performance

In general, they have their own advantages and disadvantages:

Tattu 12000mah 12v jump starter (JST1) use LiFePO4 Batteries, and we will release JST2 that use LiCoO2 Batteries. They all have great price and high quality.

title: Inground Pool Skimmer Basket - Clayton Lambert

description.text:
I have an in-ground pool built in the 70's. The skimmers are unusual by today's standards, being a rectangular box roughly 8" x 6". This style was made by a company called Clayton-Lambert. Finding replacement baskets is a chore, being special order and expensive. On top of that, they are very flimsy plastic (think strawberry crate) and last 1 or 2 seasons (sometime less if they get over stuffed with leaf debris) before becoming too brittle and splitting apart.

This is a 1st attempt at designing and printing a suitable replacement and it is working quite well. 1/8" bottom and side walls with 1/8" grid holes for filtration. This is substantially more robust than commercially available and provides slightly better filtration. I reused a handle from a broken basket and pop riveted it in place. I used white PETG as it has a little give, but is capable of being outside all summer.

Niche audience to say the least, but drop a comment if you find this useful.

title: Spring Delta/kossel bed support for 2020 bar

description.text:
Spring support that fits on a 2020 bar with a aluminum heatbed + glass plate (total height 6mm **).
Printed with PETG or ABS for having no problem with the heatbed temperature.
I use 3 of these on a Delta/Kossel plus from Anycubic with a 240 mm heatbed + 240 mm glass plate(it can be used also with a different model/size printer).

**the updated version can be used also with a 3mm tall bed (only glass or only heatbed).

You need these material :
-1 M3 screw and 1 M3 nut for fixing the plate;
-1 M4 20mm / 25mm screw and 1 M4 nut to fix to the 2020 bar;
-1 spring (max 8mm diameter), the length depends on the length of the M4 screw and the force of the spring.

EDIT 04/09/17 :
Uploaded the base_2020_v2 , it's more stable and grants the screw to stay vertically fixed.
The base now requires 3 M4 screws :
-2 are used with 2 square nuts o t nuts to fix the base to the 2020 bar (i use 8mm lenght screws)
-1 is used to support the bed(25mm / 30mm lenght), this screw is fixed to the base through 2 M4-7mm square nuts (1 upside and 1 downside).
I suggest to use 2 washer at the ends of the spring.

EDIT 07/09/17 :
-Uploaded the base_2020_v2 for standard M4 nuts (instead of square nuts), same requirements as the square version ,only different type of nuts.
-Uploaded bed support for 3mm tall bed version (only glass or only heatbed).
-Renamed all files, it's all more clear now :)

description.text:
A gantry clip and corner mounts to help secure your Replicator 2 while transporting it.  
The gantry clip will help to prevent your gantry from moving along the x axis during shipping. Place the long straight clip over the belts. Snap the C clips onto the gantry rods.  
The corner mounts also secure your gantry and motor. Each mount has a shallow notch and a deep notch. Place a zip tie across the shallow notch and secure around the gantry and the motor. When it's time to remove the zip ties, place your clippers in the deep notch for safe, easy access to cut the zip ties free.

any amount will work

I have a PowerSpec 3D Pro 2 Printer an it works wonderfully\

If you have ReplicatorG you might have to guess the scaling ratio. Personally mine was scaled 10.25 times larger to work.

Cut away raft around center hole and remove support material through hole.

title: Wheel center cap (no logo) (fits Honda, Volvo rims)

description.text:
Wheel cap without logo (have another one with logo glued on top, but requires lots of work to be usable, flat-top is much simpler IMO).
Outer diameter 56mm, height up to "holding circle" 12.3mm. Fits Honda Prelude 15" wheels, Volvo S70 17" 5-spoke rims and few others i know.
I can also upload solidworks model if you want to customize it, on request.
Printed in ABS, holds well, not rattling, but can be removed easy too when needed. If you want it to be almost permanent - print at 101% scale (maybe more, depends on material/shrinkage) and it will be impossible to remove without breaking.

description.text:
UPDATE: I edited a few things on this one. THe most important is the threat. I removed a chamfer that made it impossible to srev the funel onto the engine. Additionaly to this I smoothed out the gripping surface for the fingers a bit..

This is an screw-in oil funel for old GSXR's from the late 80's and 90's. The good old oil colled and the first water cooled ones..

The Funel is desinged to be screwed into the oil inlet.
The funel has 3 venting holes and a grippy pattern to work oily hands.

Im pretty sure that the funel will also works with other models like the old bandits, the GSX-F's and so on..

I want to give credit to https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:857406 by MrPenn.

remixed_from.title: Estes Proto X Nano Quadcopter Carrying Case

description.text: Local Motors recently started selling the Estes Proto X in our retail stores and on our website, http://www.localmotors.com/shop. Inspired by this thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:214642, we decided to try to make our own case, which we may include with the aircraft when you buy it from us. After 5 or six iterations, we have a case that holds the quad well, and allows you to takeoff and land in the case.
Print one of each STL, 10% infill at 0.2mm works fine. The hinge in ours is a .04" diameter welding rod. Enjoy!

description.text:
Based on the source tensioner by BoldBadger, which offers no mechanical way of tensioning, I drafted this remix, borrowing and scaling down a GT2 gear with 8 teeth from source by droftarts.

Added the brace piece to push on top of gears to keep gear axles from snapping off under tension.

Will need more work to make perfect, but go easy on me, I haven't had my 3d printer more than 2 months... Will revise this as soon as I print and try the part out.

Edit 08 July 2017
Printed out the parts in various material and the poles for the gears keep snapping off.
Will have to redesign with screws for the gears or other improvement. Sorry for the waste of filament for any of you who printed it!

title: Soutien à la SGDQ 2017 by dantego
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Organisés par le site Speed Demos Archive, L'Awesome Games Done Quick et le Summer Games Done Quick sont des marathons de speedrun annuels (Premier marathon datant de janvier 2010). Afin de lever des fonds au bénéfice d'associations caritatives, principalement pour Médecins sans frontières ( SGDQ) et Prevent Cancer Foundation (AGDQ).
L'intégralité de l'évènement est diffusée sur la plateforme de streaming Twitch durant 1 semaine, et rediffusé en direct par des commentateurs français.

Stream officiel :
twitch.tv/gamesdonequick

Stream FR :
LeFrenchRestream
twitch.tv/lefrenchrestream

Le but de ce fichier est de rassembler les communautés de gamers et de printer/maker 3D (parfois intimement liées) autour d'une cause commune et humanitaire.

Si vous choisissez de télécharger ce fichier, vous vous engagez à faire un don pour l’événement du montant de votre choix, car même un simple euro peut être d'une précieuse aide.
Afin d'effectuer votre don, veuillez suivre ce lien.
ATTENTION, LE SITE EST EN ANGLAIS !
Vous pouvez voir que certains paliers de don sont éligibles à des tombolas et que vous avez la possibilité d'influencer certains des défis proposés aux speedrunners. Cependant, si l'étape ne vous intéresse pas, vous avez également le choix de la passer.

https://gamesdonequick.com/tracker/donate/sgdq2017

Laissez un petit message de soutien pendant que vous faites votre don dans la case prévue à cet effet, et concluez le par : #Impression3DSoutienLaSGDQ.

Si vous êtes sur Twitter, postez l’image de votre print à @FrenchRestream et/ou à @GamesDoneQuick avec les Hashtag : #SGDQ2017 #Impression3DSoutienLaSGDQ.

Et comme nous le disons si bien durant cet évènement : BOURREZ LES DONS !!

Si vous souhaitez des renseignements ou simplement me contacter, vous pouvez me trouver sur FB et Twitter.
FB : Dantego modeling creations
Twitter : @Dantego_P

description.text:
Este proyecto es una práctica para el curso de EDX, se irá modificando conforme se avance en el mismo.
La mayor parte del diseño ha sido ralizado con THINKER cad, las piezas que no se han sacado del repositorio de DYOR han sido diseñadas por alca3d con freecad y se encuentran en mi repositorio de thingiverse.
En concreto son tres piezas:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2402336
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1524970
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2436006

Videos de la construcción:
https://youtu.be/WhFx7pNUEeI
https://youtu.be/YI50_DSEhC0
https://youtu.be/of22tpVPt3Y

Archivo de la electrónica con Fritzing:

Link relacionados con el proyecto:
Portal de formación robot DYOR: http://dyor.roboticafacil.es/
Curso MOOC EdX: https://www.edx.org/course/disena-fabrica-y-programa-tu-propio-upvalenciax-dyor101x
Blog robótica de la UPV: http://robotica.webs.upv.es
Twitter (@roboticaUPV): https://twitter.com/roboticaUPV
Facebook (robótica UPV): https://www.facebook.com/roboticaUPV

LISTADO DE COMPONENTES. HC SR 04 sensor de distancia por ultrasonidos.
HC-06 Modulo Buetooth.
DS 3115 Servo de rotación continua.
SG 90 Microservo.
KY-033 Módulo de rastreo por infrarrojos.
MAX 7219 Matriz de led 8X8.
Arduino nano, CPU= Atemega 328.
Shield de expansión 3.0 para arduino nano.

Funciones del robot DYOR:

-Selección del modulo bluetooth para la conexion y desconexión.
-Control de microservo con dos posiciones en las que podemos regular los ángulos de final y parada.
-Uso de función parpadeo de la matriz de diodos led con idicación sonora, donde podemos definir los dibujos.En el siguinte enlace podemos confeccionar de forma sencialla los dibujos que imaginemos.:
https://www.riyas.org/2013/12/online-led-matrix-font-generator-with.html
El software que nos permite hacer esto, esta en el siguiente enlace:
https://www.minitronica.com/matrices-led-8x8-arduino-max7219/
Hay que implementarlo a mano una vez confeccionado el programa con visualino, ya que este no dispone entre sus componentes la matriz de leds.
-Control manual de movimientos através del smartphon y via bluetooth.(up, atras, derecha, izquierda y parada).
-Control de movimientos con el sensor acelerómetro.
-Selección del modo seguidor de linea.(Linea negra sobre fondo blanco).
Realizado con dos sensores de infrarojos digitales.
-Selección del modo follow me.
Con el uso del sensor ultrasónico que permite medir distancias en cm.

description.text:

Edit(7/3/17). File is now fixed.

Instructions:

  1. The inside surface must be smoothed. Something like XTC-3D is recommended to save time.
  2. A mold release agent must be used before you pour silicone so you can separate it after it has cured. Ease release 200 or smooth-on universal mold release are some examples.
  3. Enjoy!

Pegs and female peg holes are designed with 2 mm difference for tolerance.

This is an upgrade of the stand from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:128986. I purchased a bare charging board from dx.com (http://dx.com/p/qi-standard-wireless-charging-transmitter-module-green-269662) and integrated it into this stand. The 2013 version of the Nexus 7 supports the Qi wireless charging standard, and this board from DX is the lowest cost Qi compliant board that I have been able to find. Wireless charging is awesome because I don't have to plug in the charger daily. I made one charge stand for my night stand and one charge stand for my desk at work and now my battery is always full! One issue is that both of the coils were damaged in shipping. You can see in the picture that upper left corner of the gray material behind the charging coil is chipped off. Everything still seems to be working even with the corner chipped. When I notified DX they gave me a refund for the charger boards.

• Laser cut the parts from 1/8" plywood. I used baltic birch plywood.
  • Use hot glue to glue in the charge coil.
  • Use hot glue to glue the circuit board to the back of the charge coil.
  • Use wood glue to glue the frame together
  • Charge!
This is a trophy...

description.text:
I had problems with vibration on the GoPro, when I used it in the car, becasue of the long arm of my suction mount. To get rid of that, I designed this adapter part, to mount the camera closer to the mount.

I decided to print the whole thing in two parts and glue them together afterwards, because I thought the teeth are printed much better, if they are flat on the build plate and not upright. I included the one piece version too, if someone wants to print it, but I havn't tested it (!!!!).

For the GoPro mount, I used a normal flat adhesive mounting plate. A 3D printed one like this should also work well:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:40282

I got my suction mount in a pack similar to this (the adhesive plate is from that too):
https://www.amazon.de/gp/product/B018Z358JG/ref=s9u_simh_gw_i1?ie=UTF8&pd_rd_i=B018Z358JG&pd_rd_r=G4WRKAB7GN13S138N5F0&pd_rd_w=EKo9J&pd_rd_wg=8I46d&pf_rd_m=A3JWKAKR8XB7XF&pf_rd_s=&pf_rd_r=6PBR0MFP73TMXKSHTZPP&pf_rd_t=36701&pf_rd_p=31e89994-24c5-4f2a-aa69-5e32e91703a1&pf_rd_i=desktop
but if you wouldn't spend that much money for so many accessories, this product sould work well, too:
http://www.ebay.de/itm/Suction-Cup-Mount-Holder-Tripod-Mount-Adapter-For-GoPro-Hero-3-3-2-1-Camera-/311435793725?hash=item488305153d:g:qPkAAOSw0JpV4-Ur

description.text:
Hi!

This is a simple customizable stone/rock/asteroid generator.

May be useful for board games, decoration, dioramas....

Every customization generates 10 random stones based on customizer parameters.
Parameters:

  • Number of corners: More corners generates more spheric stones.
  • Z scale: Affects to height of stone.

Also a good stub for OpenSCAD users.

Hope you find it useful

Have fun!

PD: See also: Rock Formation Generator (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2416545)

Printer:

BQ Prusa i3 Hephestos

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

0.1 - 0.2 mms

Infill:

10% - 20%

Notes:

TIP: Reorient the figure in the Slicer looking for a good bed adhesion. (I use 'Lay Flat' in Cura slicer)

You may need supports for some stones depending of how you reorient the figure.

description.header: How to create a Rock formation using Cura
description.text: STEP 1: Load some models STEP 2: Disable 'Ensure models are kept appart' in Preferences Step 3: Move, Scale, Rotate and build your own structure.

I always figured this would be funny to have as an RC car body. (So you could boast, "I just beat your car with with mom's minivan!") I don't have a good reference for any particular RC car chassis, so it's quite likely that this will need some further work to be made to fit on body mounting posts.

Anyhow enjoy!

--- Edit 7/4/2016 ---
Uploaded the .blend file just because. Layer 2 has the same mesh as the .stl, but layer 1 has all the lower poly and construction meshing stuff. (So you might get an idea of my workflow. Just some box modeling for a template and building the working mesh over that where it's easier to flow edges and adjust detail.) I'd figure having that may be easier for remixing or whatever than a mesh with 2 levels of subdiv already applied. Of course my scaling here is pretty arbitrary (no references at the moment), so it could be adapted to get at least one important dimension close - and adjust the body to fit from there.

Also if anyone has a 3D modeled chassis reference available at the proper scale, do comment - and maybe I'll get around to making this fit over it. But you do have the original .blend now and you're free to remix it too.

I designed these as I was fed up with using cable ties to keep the training gear on my 450 size heli.
The clips are designed for a 450 size heli with 5mm skids and 3mm training gear rods.
The clips simply slip over the training gear rods and then clip onto the skids, simple as that.
There is a right hand and left hand version and you will need two of each.
I had to file out the 3mm holes on all the clips I made to get the training gear rods through but it works really well so no need to leave the training gear attached all the time

Ejercicios de programación:

Ejercicio 1: Aplicación de control remoto mediante bluetooth (https://youtu.be/Ya5OcyE7Itk)
He creado una App con AppInventor para controlar el robot a distancia desde un dispositivo móvil mediante bluetooth. Esta app permite en control de los motores de rotación continua (adelante, atrás, izquierda y derecha) así como el control de los servos de posición (pierna izquierda y derecha). Podéis ver imagen de la interfaz de la app con el resto de imágenes.

Ejercicio 2: Tarea autónoma del robot (https://youtu.be/FVcrThyvUGk)
La tarea que realizará el robot consiste en un seguimiento de línea mediante el sensor de infrarrojos llevando una pelota entre las pinzas del robot para simular un regate de un jugador de fútbol. Esta acción finaliza después de un tiempo establecido en un contador. A continuación el robot simula un tiro a puerta metiendo un gol. Esta segunda acción se realiza mediante un giro de 90º del robot y varios movimientos de la pinza accionada por los servos de posición para lanzar el balón.

Robot hecho para un curso. Es una persona con banderas para comunicarse con el alfabeto semáforo, de la OMI (Organización Marítima Internacional).
La posición de los brazos determina una letra/número. Mi idea es que al mandarle realizar una letra, aparezca en la matriz de leds.
Los adornos están hechos con rotuladores y cartulinas.
Este código hoy en día es usado por algún grupo de boyscouts.
Tenéis más información en esta dirección de wikipedia
https://es.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sem%C3%A1foro_(comunicaci%C3%B3n)

description.text:
Hello, I present to you the cheapest 5.8g VSWR meter for measuring your FPV antennas. Although it's a far cry from an Anritsu/ Agilent VNA, it gives the best accuracy for the buck!

A couple years back, I built an analog vswr meter using an old school multi-meter. While that works great as a tool for tuning my DIY FPV antennas (on my youtube channel), having to read the needle off a self-conjured swr scale (printed on paper) is not ideal for accuracy. Thus, I made this to achieve better accuracy, build + demo in the video above.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y0CZb1XxvPY

Parts Needed:

  1. 1-8000MHz AD8318 RF Logarithmic Detector (from banggood, analog, etc)
  2. Directional RF Coupler ~ 6GHZ or higher (from ebay)
  3. 20db RF attenuator/ micro pad ~ 6GHZ (from ebay)
  4. Digital multi-meter with reading of 2 decimal places (from dx, banggood, etc)
  5. Spare test leads for digital multi-meter (from dx, banggood,etc)
  6. 5.8ghz 200mw video transmitter with SMA / RP-SMA (getfpv, banggood, etc)
  7. Various RF adapters -refer to video (from ebay)
  8. 3S lipo pack (from local hobby shop) or 9v battery (almost anywhere)
  9. JST male and female plugs, 3S balance connector (from ebay, aliexpress, etc) or 9v battery connector strap (from local hardware shop)
    Tools:
  10. Hot glue gun and hot glue
  11. Soldering iron, flux and solder lead
  12. Computer or smart device (for the computing of standing wave ratio)

description.text: This bracket attaches my phone to the metal shade of a small desk lamp. It is attached with a single small bolt and nut. Lamp has a weighted base and adjustable neck. Intended to hold the phone in a steady well-illuminated position for recording videos or timelapse photography of drawings. Here is a short time lapse sketch video recorded with this clip: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=s5EMarSBe0o (The app I use to record time lapse videos is called Frameograph.) Designed for an iPhone 5c, but other devices might fit. The clip area cross section is 59mm by 8.5mm. I have a low-wattage compact fluorescent bulb in this lamp. Be careful if you try something similar with a bulb that gets very hot - you don't want the plastic to melt.

Note: I accidentally snapped off part of the so-called final clip. The reinforced version is actually more recent; it is slightly thicker and has ribs to strengthen the corner that broke. I'm learning design principles and PLA properties by trial and error!
Printed in PLA with 0.2 mm layer height, 3 top & bottom layers, 2 perimeters, and 0.1 rectilinear infill. I had to drill out the hole in the base in order for the intended bolt to fit easily.

description.text:
This a model of the SCV-70 White Base from MSG (GUNDAM).

"In the Universal Century timeline of the fictional Gundam universe, the SCV-70 (LMSD-71, MSC-02) White Base is a Pegasus-class mobile suit carrier deployed by the Earth Federation. Through the first part of One Year War, the White Base's registration name was unknown to the Principality of Zeon forces, so they referred to her by the codename 'Trojan Horse' (木馬, mokuba, "wooden horse"), presumably because of her unusual equine shape. After the war, she was re-designated MSC-02 even though the ship herself was destroyed at A Baoa Qu."

From Gundam Wikia

title: Tronxy X3 heat bed carrier replacement

description.text:
Don't download the OpenSCAD file. It is an empty file like the name suggests. This is all about the other file. The OpenSCAD file is just there because thingiverse doesn't accept entries without a file type known by thingiverse

The Tronxy X3 heat bed carrier plate is not useful. Mainly because of the wrong distance between the screws that holds the wheels. I know of many workarounds that you can find here on thingiverse, but sorry I don't like them.

With my new 200W heater in the near I feared that the acrylic plate could bend additionally. So I decided that I need a replacement made from aluminium.

Because of the lack of the right tools and enough time I looked for a way to get it made by a professional manufacturer. I designed the new carrier plate as a drop in replacement of the old one with the nice free software from the company Schaeffer AG. It is named Frontplatten Designer (Front Panel Designer) and can get downloaded here. This program allowed me to order the plate directly from the Company.

My design includes additional drill holes to make it possible to use 3 wheels instead of 4 and to mount the bed with 3 screws. My new CNC milled bed has holes for this. 4 holes are over-determined and make only trouble, but they are still there.

Needles to say that the new carrier fits perfectly, no wobble at all. The specific weight of aluminium is a little bit more than twice of that of acryl, but the aluminium plate is only 3mm height, that is less than the half of the acrylic plate, so I doubt that there will be much more weight.

I have attached the file for the Frontplatten Designer so you can view it and, if you want, to allow you to order it. And of course you can customise it, if you think I made it wrong.
Be aware that my file doesn't include the logo and the aluminium is not anodized.

I am not affiliated with the company Schaeffer AG. I don't get anything if anyone is ordering anything from them. But I got a discount because I allowed them to place their logo on the carrier and publish it here.

Printer:

Tronxy X3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter
